message.content:
We begin by checking the few places where either “Peter” or “Cheryl” appear. In the given list we see:

• “Andrew is Peter’s ancestor.”

• “Cheryl is Jennifer’s ancestor.”

Looking further, we try to “build” each chain.

For Peter:
• Andrew is Peter’s ancestor.
• Also, elsewhere it is given “Andrew is Thomas’s descendant” and “Thomas is Alan’s descendant.” (and even further up the chain there are names like Paul, Kathleen, Noah, and Carl, etc.) So Peter’s chain (from his ancestors) is something like:
  Alan → Thomas → Andrew → Peter,
plus additional connections available in that family (for example, “Paul is Alan’s ancestor” and “Kathleen is Paul’s ancestor,” etc.). In short, Peter sits on one branch of the family tree.

For Cheryl:
• We are told “Cheryl is Jennifer’s ancestor.”
• There is also “Beverly is Jennifer’s descendant,” and going on we see:
  Cheryl → Jennifer → Beverly → Deborah → Charlotte → … → (Alice, then Gregory, then Diana, then George, etc.)
This chain is entirely separate; it involves no names (like Andrew, Thomas, Alan, etc.) that appear in Peter’s chain.

Since no statements link any member from Peter’s family tree to any in Cheryl’s, we have no evidence that either Peter is an ancestor/descendant of Cheryl or that the two share a common descendant. (Of course, two totally separate families do not “share” any ancestor unless it is stated that they merge at some point.) 

Thus, none of the provided choices correctly describes a relationship between Peter and Cheryl.

<ANSWER>5</ANSWER>
